text.b: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto
1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

text.b: APPENDIX C: Existing Traffic Synchro Report
APPENDIX E: Future Background Traffic Synchro Report
APPENDIX H: Future Total Traffic Synchro Report
1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: Madison Briar Hill Ltd. is proposing to redevelop the former Toronto District School Board site situated
at the northeast corner of Dufferin Street and Briar Hill Avenue. The subject development is located in
Toronto’s Briar Hill-Belgravia Neighbourhood and is bounded by private property to the North, Dufferin
Street to the west, Briar Hill Avenue to the south and the site access driveway to the east. Figure 1-1
This application is for a Zoning By-Law Amendment and Site Plan Application. The site municipal
address is 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, Toronto. This Transportation Impact Study has been prepared as part
of the application, and adheres to the “Guidelines for the Preparation of Transportation Impact Studies,
2013” circulated by the City of Toronto.
The proposed development will consist of 136 residential units with 308 m
ground floor. Located on the north-east corner of Dufferin Street and Briar Hill Avenue, the ground floor
retail will be situated on the east side of Dufferin Street. A 1,490 m
public park is retained for the corner
of Dufferin Street and Briar Hill Avenue with the residential units set back from the park. Table 1.1
provides detailed statistics of the proposed development.

text.b: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: Residential vehicular access will be from Briar Hill Avenue via a service driveway located at the most
easterly edge of the site. Access to the parking levels will also be from this service driveway.
Pedestrian site access will be accommodated on the existing sidewalks located along Dufferin Street and
Briar Hill Avenue. Numerous site walkways will connect to these existing sidewalks. TTC bus stops are
located on the south-east corner (northbound bus service) and the north-west corner (southbound bus
service) of Dufferin Street and Briar Hill Avenue.
The site plan is illustrated in Figure 1-2.

text.b: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: The following provides a description and classification of each roadway within the study area. Figure
2-1 illustrates the existing lane configuration within the study area.
The existing road network in the study area includes: Dufferin Street, Briar Hill Avenue and Locksley
Dufferin Street is a four-lane north/south major arterial road with a posted speed limit of 50 km/h.
Briar Hill Avenue is a two-lane collector roadway serving the surrounding residential neighbourhood.
As Briar Hill Junior Public School was originally located on the subject site, traffic calming measures,
such as speed bumps, were installed and the posted speed limit is reduced to 30 km/h.
Locksley Avenue is a two-lane local roadway with the main purpose of providing residential access.

text.b: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: The proposed development is located within an area with accessibility to public transit services. Toronto
Transit Commission (TTC) services are available along Dufferin Street. The subject site is located within
a 15 minute walking distance from Glencairn subway station and a 25 minute walking distance of
Eglinton West Subway Station on the Yonge-University-Spadina Subway.
The TTC routes within the study area are illustrated in Figure 2-2.

text.b: Figure 2-2: Toronto Transit Commission (TTC) Transit Service Network

page.text: The TTC routes within the study area are as follows:
29 Dufferin is a northbound-southbound bus route. The route connects to Wilson Station on the
Yonge-University-Spadina Subway and serves Dufferin Station on the Bloor-Danforth Subway.
This service operates with three minute headways during the a.m. and p.m. peak hour and much
of the rest of the day. Half of the buses short turn to the north of the subject site (29A) during the
weekday a.m. and p.m. peak periods.

text.b: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: Existing cycling infrastructure in the area is as follows:
Marlee Avenue has northbound and southbound painted bicycle lanes.
Roselawn Avenue has eastbound and westbound panted bicycle lanes.
York Beltline Trail is an off-road, multi-use trail with an eastbound-westbound alignment. It is
approximately 2.2km in length however, a connection to the Kay Gardner Beltline Trail is
possible east of Allen Road. This trail is located four blocks south of the proposed development.
In order to evaluate the existing traffic conditions, study area intersections were surveyed. Table 2.1
summarizes the source and dates of the traffic data utilized in this study. Traffic counts are appended to

text.b: Table 2.1: Existing Traffic Volume Collection Dates

page.text: To assess existing traffic conditions in the study area, traffic counts were conducted at the signalized
intersections of Dufferin Street and Briar Hill Avenue and the unsignalized intersection of Briar Hill
Avenue and Locksley Avenue. These traffic counts were conducted on Tuesday June 18
7:00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. and from 4:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m. in order to capture the a.m. and p.m. peak
periods and to determine the weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hour volumes.
Figure 2-3 illustrates the existing traffic volumes for the weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours.
The school building currently located on the site is no longer in use and does not generate any traffic

text.b: Proposed Residential Development: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue
1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: The signalized and unsignalized capacity analysis for the study area was undertaken using Synchro
version 8.0 based on the Highway Capacity Manual (2010) methodology adhering to the City of Toronto
Guidelines for Using Synchro 7, 2010. Signal timing was based on signal timing plans received from the
City, which are appended to this report in Appendix B. The peak hour factors (PHF) applied in the
analysis have been calculated based on the traffic counts undertaken by LEA. The area type has been
Table 2.2 below tabulates both weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hour levels of service under existing traffic
conditions. The Dufferin Street and Briar Hill Avenue signalized intersection is currently operating at
acceptable levels of service. All four quadrants of the intersection are adequately equipped with
sidewalks and crosswalks to facilitate pedestrian movement. The detailed capacity analysis for existing
traffic can be found in Appendix C.

text.b: Table 2.2: Existing Levels of Service - Signalized Intersection

page.text: The existing unsignalized intersection of Briar Hill Avenue and Locksley Avenue function with good
levels of service during both the weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours. The results of the capacity analysis
for the unsignalized intersections are summarized in Table 2.3.

text.b: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto
Table 2.3: Existing Levels of Service - Unsignalized Intersections

page.text: For the future traffic conditions, this traffic impact study considers a five-year horizon to the year 2018.
The sections below outline our assumptions for the future background traffic conditions. A background
corridor growth rate of 1% has been applied along Dufferin Street to account for future background
increases in traffic. This growth rate was arrived at by calculating the annual percentage change of traffic
volumes for the northbound and southbound flows on Dufferin Street. The annual growth rates for
northbound and southbound movements on Dufferin Street at Briar Hill Avenue are illustrated in Table

text.i: *historical traffic count data obtained from the City of Toronto ('04) and LEA Consulting Ltd. ('92, '93, '96)

text.b: Table 3.1: Dufferin Street at Briar Hill Avenue Corridor Growth Rate
1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: In discussion with City of Toronto Staff, it was identified that there are a number of developments
proposed in the vicinity of the subject site. It was determined that anticipated background development
traffic should include the following sites:
Traffic associated with these background developments is illustrated in Appendix D. A diagram of the
weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hour future background traffic volumes can be found in Figure 3-1.

text.b: Proposed Residential Development: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue
1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: Intersection capacity analysis was conducted under future background traffic conditions using existing
signal timings where applicable. Table 3.3 summarizes the results of the signalized intersection capacity
analysis for the weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours. Detailed results of the future background traffic
capacity analysis can be found in Appendix E.
In the future background traffic scenario, the intersection of Dufferin Street and Briar Hill Avenue is
operating with acceptable levels of service during the weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hour. Some queuing
may be experienced with the southbound through and the northbound through right movements. All
movements are anticipated to function at Level of Service “C” or better.

text.b: Table 3.3: Future Background Traffic - Signalized Levels of Service

page.text: Analysis of the unsignalized intersection within the study suggests that all movements will operate at
very good levels of service with all movements operating at Level of Service “A”. Table 3.4 below
summarizes the results of the unsignalized intersection analysis for the weekday a.m. and p.m. peak

text.b: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto
Table 3.4: Future Background Traffic - Unsignalized Levels of Service
1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue will be primarily a residential development consisting of stacked townhouses and
of ground-oriented retail. The residential trip generation rate applied has been arrived at through
the use of a proxy site survey at the nearby 1001 Roselawn Avenue residential development. The retail
trips have been generated based on parking supply and the assumption that each space in the parking lot
will turnover twice in an hour. There is no existing traffic to or from the site as the existing school
Residential trip generation was calculated using surveys conducted by LEA Consulting Ltd at 1001
This residential development is similar in number of residential units to the proposed, and is located less
than 500 metres from the subject site. Table 4.1 summarizes the residential trip generation rates applied.
The specific tenants of the at grade retail portion of this development are, as of yet, unknown. It is our
understanding that the intent of the space is for businesses that service the local community. During the
weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours, the trip generation rate for the retail component of the proposed
development is conservatively anticipated to be constrained by the available occupancy of on-site
parking spaces. The average customer dwell time has been assumed at 30 minutes per customer, based on
our experience with retail in the City of Toronto. Based on this assumption, each parking space will
Of the trips generated by the at grade retail, some trips will be comprised of traffic already passing by the
site. This type of traffic is considered “pass-by” traffic. The ITE Trip Generation Handbook identifies
that 36% of retail traffic during the weekday p.m. peak hour is comprised of “pass-by” traffic. This is
consistent with our own experiences for small retail. As the retail in this development will be primarily
servicing the local community, the same type of “pass-by” activity has been considered for the weekday

text.b: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: The following Table 4.2 summarizes the total trips expected to be generated by the development.
The proposed development is projected to generate 49 two-way weekday a.m. peak hour trips and 49
two-way weekday p.m. peak hour trips that will be added to the network with 6 weekday a.m. peak hour
trips and 6 weekday p.m. peak hour trips destined to the site coming from traffic that would pass the site
in the absence of the development.

text.i: Potential Traffic Generated by ‘As-of-Right’ Zoning Permission

page.text: In order to assess the traffic generated by ‘as-of-right’ zoning permissions on the site, two By-Laws were
reviewed. The site straddles both the former City of York and City of North York. The portion of the site
within the former City of York is zoned R2 in By-Law 1-83 and the portion in the former City of North
York is zoned R5 in By-Law 7625. Both zonings have similar permitted uses with the highest traffic
generators being schools and public libraries. The more conservative of the two building size limits has
been assumed, which is from the City of York, with a maximum floor space index of 0.4. According to
City of York ‘as-of-right’ zoning, the maximum floor area of either a school or library on the 8,000 m
. This is larger than the elementary school building located on the site which is no longer
in use. This amount of floor area is large for a public library and the building would likely include some
Both an elementary school and a public library have been considered as possible high traffic generators.
As the existing school building is no longer in use, potential traffic generated by ‘as-of-right’ zoning has
been calculated using the ITE Trip Generation Manual, 9
Edition. Trip rates have been adjusted for the
local auto modal splits as follows:
70% for workers destined to the area, applied to the school trips; and,
86% for discretionary trips to the area applied to the public library trips.
The ITE Trip Generation Manual rate has been assumed to be representative of a 95% auto modal split.
Table 4.3 shows the calculation for the traffic generated by the ‘as-of-right’ zoning permissions.

text.b: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto
Projected Gross Site Traffic For Proposed
Table 4.3: Trips Generated by 'As-of-Right' Zoning Permissions

page.text: The projected site traffic generated by the proposed development is generally lower than that generated
by the ‘as-of-right’ zoning permissions. The projected traffic is significantly lower than an elementary
school during the weekday a.m. peak hour and slightly higher than a public library during the weekday
a.m. peak hour. The reverse is true during the weekday p.m. peak hour.
Trip distribution of site traffic for the residential stacked townhouses was estimated using 2006
Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data. TTS Zones of Origin and Destination were used to
determine the trip distribution, as detailed in Appendix F. Table 4.4 below summarizes the general
directional distribution of the residential site traffic.
The general trip distribution for the retail component applied in this study is based on travel patterns
observed from the Dufferin Business Centre driveway located at 2700 Dufferin Street (west leg of
Dufferin Street and Briar Hill Avenue intersection). Retail pass-by trip distribution was based on typical
pass-by travel patterns and traffic volumes observed on Briar Hill Avenue. Appendix G details the
residential and retail trip distribution, and site traffic for individual uses.

text.b: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: Based on our understanding of the road network surrounding the site, the site traffic had been assigned as
Future total traffic volumes were derived from combining the future background traffic volumes with the
total site traffic volumes. Figure 4-2 illustrates the future total traffic volumes for the weekday a.m. and

text.b: Proposed Residential Development: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue
Proposed Residential Development: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue
1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: Intersection capacity analyses were conducted for the future traffic conditions with the same signal
timings as the future background conditions. Table 4.5 summarizes the signalized analyses results for the
future total traffic conditions for the weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours. Detailed analyses outputs can be

text.b: Table 4.5: Future Total Traffic - Signalized Levels of Service

page.text: Under future total traffic conditions, it is expected that the proposed development will place an additional
49 two-way trips on the surrounding road network during the a.m. peak hour, and 49 two-way trips in the
p.m. peak hour. For the intersection of Dufferin Street and Briar Hill Avenue there is minimal impact due
to the proposed development during the weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hour. The intersection is operating
with acceptable levels of service during the a.m. and p.m. peak hour, similar to the future background
traffic scenario. Any additional delay due to the development is generally expected to be less than one
second. This is less than the difference due to daily variations in traffic volumes and it is unlikely this
level of impact would be observable to traffic travelling through the area.
Analysis of unsignalized intersections suggests that all unsignalized intersections will operate at good
levels of service. The analysis summary is shown in Table 4.6.

text.b: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto
Table 4.6: Future Total Traffic - Unsignalized Levels of Service

page.text: Under future total traffic conditions, the unsignalized intersection of Locksley Avenue and Briar Hill
Avenue and the site access onto Briar Hill Avenue are anticipated to function at Level of Service “A”. As
with the signalized intersection, any delay increases due to the development are expected to be less than
Site generated transit trips were estimated by comparing the projected auto trips with the auto and transit
modal splits for the area. The modal splits were derived from the 2006 Transportation Tomorrow Survey.
With a residential auto modal split of 51% and a transit modal split of 45%, it is estimated that the site
will generate 34 residential transit trips during the a.m. weekday peak hour and 34 transit trips during the
p.m. weekday peak hour. With a discretionary auto modal split of 86% and a transit modal split of 13% it
is estimated that the site will generate 2 additional retail transit trips during each of the weekday a.m. and
p.m. peak hours. These additional 36 trips, during each peak hour, are expected to primarily utilize the
TTC #29 Dufferin northbound-southbound bus route, while some may choose to walk 15 minutes to the
Glencairn Subway Station or 25 minutes to the Eglinton West Subway Station.
Site generated pedestrian trips were estimated based on modal splits from the 2006 Transportation
Tomorrow Survey. Four (4) purely pedestrian trips are anticipated to be generated by the residential
portion of the development during each of the weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours. For the retail units, the
existing pedestrian modal split in the area for discretionary trips is quite low, at 1%. It is anticipated that

text.b: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: as this retail space will be community focused, the pedestrian modal split may be higher for these units.
The pedestrian traffic to the retail units is anticipated to be primarily comprised of pedestrian traffic
already in the area as well as internal trips from the residential portion of the development. It should be
noted that all transit trips begin or end as pedestrian trips. As such, the identified 36 transit trips during
each of the weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours will involve pedestrian movements around the site prior to
Pedestrian traffic destined to or from the northbound Dufferin bus will need to cross Briar Hill Avenue
and will add to the 11 weekday a.m. pedestrians and 17 weekday p.m. pedestrians currently performing
this movement. Pedestrian traffic destined to or from the southbound #29 Dufferin bus will cross
Dufferin Street on the north side of the intersection along with the 16 weekday a.m. pedestrians and 6
weekday p.m. pedestrians currently performing this movement.
The amount of pedestrians generated by the development is expected to be minor. The closest transit
service, the #29 Dufferin bus, is provided at the neighbouring signalized intersection of Dufferin Street
and Briar Hill Avenue. Pedestrians wishing to cross either Briar Hill Avenue or Dufferin Street can do so
at a signalized intersection. There are sidewalks in place along both Briar Hill Avenue and Dufferin
Street that can accommodate the projected additional pedestrian traffic.

text.b: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: The subject site is officially located in Former General Zoning By-Law 1-83 (York) jurisdiction and
Former General Zoning By-Law 7625 (North York) jurisdiction.
Given that similar sites, in the vicinity of the proposed development, fall under the City of Toronto
Comprehensive Zoning By-Law 569-2013 Policy Area 4, these parking requirements have been
reviewed. If applied, the development would require a minimum of 146 parking spaces and a maximum
of 190 parking spaces, as shown below. The current proposal indicates 161 parking spaces will be
provided, which satisfies the parking by-law requirements of 569-2013.
Table 5.1 illustrates the total parking requirements and supply (residential and retail) for the proposed

text.b: Total Parking Spaces Required as per City
Table 5.1: Parking Requirement (Zoning By-Law 569-2013 Policy Area 4)

page.text: Passenger pick-up and drop off activity can be accommodated either on Briar Hill Avenue, for very brief
stops during off-peak hours, or in the retail and visitor parking area of the parking garage for longer
stops. The low traffic volumes and wide width of Briar Hill Avenue allows for maneuverability around a

text.b: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: The City of Toronto bicycle parking requirements according to Zoning By-Law 569-2013 has also been
reviewed. A minimum of 123 long term bicycle spaces and 18 short term bicycle parking spaces are
required under the by-law. It is our understanding that the intent is to meet the requirement as a
minimum. Table 5.2 summarizes the requirement under the by-law.

text.b: Table 5.2: Minimum Bicycle Parking Requirement (Zoning By-Law 569-2013: Bicycle Zone 1)

page.text: The City of Toronto Zoning Bylaw loading requirements for the proposed development are illustrated in

text.b: Table 6.1: Minimum Loading Requirement (Zoning By-Law 569-2013: Policy Area 1)

page.text: As per by-law requirement, the proposed development will provide one Type “G” loading space.
Loading activity is expected to occur in this space. Vehicle swept paths for a City of Toronto Garbage
Truck are illustrated in Appendix J. There is sufficient space provided for a truck to perform the

text.b: 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, City of Toronto

page.text: The development proposal is for 136 stacked townhouse units with 308 m
Under existing conditions, the Dufferin Street and Briar Hill Avenue signalized intersection operates at
an acceptable level of service during both the weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours. The existing
unsignalized intersection of Briar Hill Avenue and Locksley Avenue functions with a good level of
service during the weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours.
The proposed development is projected to generate 49 and 49 two-way primary trips new to the traffic
network during the weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours, respectively.
The additional site traffic is minimal and will not be observable within the study area. Under future total
traffic conditions, it is expected that the signalized intersection at Dufferin Street and Briar Hill Avenue
will continue to operate at acceptable levels of service. Similarly, the unsignalized intersection at
Locksley Avenue and Briar Hill Avenue will continue to function at Level of Service “A” under future
The number of auto parking spaces, bicycle parking spaces, and loading spaces all meet or exceed the
requirements of the City of Toronto Zoning By-Law 569-2013.
The proposed development can be accommodated on the existing roadway network.
Suite 900, 625 Cochrane Drive, Markham, ON, L3R 9R9 CANADA

text.b: Re: Terms of Reference - Traffic Impact Study for the Proposed Residential Development at 1100

page.text: LEA Consulting Ltd. (LEA) has prepared the following letter detailing the development proposal located
at 1100 Briar Hill Avenue, Toronto. The proposed development consists of 136 residential units. The
following details our proposed terms of reference to conduct a Traffic Impact Study for your review and
The proposed development will consist of 136 residential units including 3 live/work units and 133
of retail situated on the ground floor. Located on the north-east
corner of Dufferin Street and Briar Hill Avenue, the ground floor retail will be located on the east side of
public park is retained for the corner of Dufferin Street and Briar Hill
Avenue with the residential units set back from the park. Residential vehicular access will be from Briar
Hill Avenue via a service driveway located at the most easterly edge of the site.
The subject site is located south of Stayner Avenue, west of Locksley Avenue, east of Dufferin Street
and north of Briar Hill Avenue in Toronto’s Briar Hill/Belgravia neighbourhood. The following
Turning movement counts of the unsignalized intersections identified above have been collected for the
weekday a.m., and p.m. peak periods through surveys conducted by LEA on Tuesday June 18
The timing of the proposed development suggests a five horizon year (year 2018) from the date of this
TIS (2013). A review of historical background counts shows a 1.0% per annum growth rate along
Dufferin Street. A 1.0% per annum growth rate, above the background developments listed below, will
be included along Dufferin Street to account for future background increases in traffic.
The anticipated background development traffic will include the following sites:
1. 2811 Dufferin Street: proposed 1,980 m² office use; and
2. 2462 Dufferin Street: a proposed 3,618 m² office use and 764 m
We understand that the City will confirm if the same and/or additional background developments shall be
considered for the current traffic study. Upon confirmation, LEA staff will need to meet with City Staff
to review the relevant background documents.

i.b: 5.0 Trip Generation, Trip Distribution and Trip Assignment

page.text: The trip generation rate for the residential use shall be based on the rate observed from a proxy survey of
1001 Roselawn Avenue, Toronto which LEA conducted on Wednesday June 26
condominium building contains 138 residential units, is located south-east of the proposed development
site and is within a 10 minute walking distance.
The trip distribution will be based on traffic survey data for the traffic analysis zone as presented in the
2006 Transportation Tomorrow Survey. Trips will then be assigned to the existing road network on the
basis of the adjacent road connections and, if present, existing turning restrictions.
The intersection analysis for signalized and unsignalized intersections will be undertaken using Synchro
Version 8 software, adhering to analysis methodology outlined in the Highway Capacity Manual 2000.
The input parameters shall be based on the suggested values as outlined in the City of Toronto
Residents will access the proposed site via one (1) site access from Briar Hill Avenue. The parking
requirements shall be in accordance with the City of Toronto Zoning By-Law No. 569-2013.
Should you have any questions or comments regarding this proposed Terms of Reference, please contact
Karen Montain at 905-470-0015 extension 236 or Elysia Leung at extension 259.
Elysia Leung, MA MPlan MCIP RPP
